titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Agricultural Society of Kings County records 1977.396
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-11-25 16:38:45 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Agricultural Society of Kings County records
did.abstract: One multipage document containing the Agricultural Society of Kings County's constitution, bylaws, list of officers, goals, dues list, and meeting minutes, dated March 1807.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single document.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Agricultural Society of Kings County was established by major landowners Jeremiah Johnson, Hendrick Lott, Leffert Lefferts, Jeremiah Lott, John Terhune, and John Vanderveer between December 27, 1806 and March 2, 1807. The focus of the Society was to promote agriculture, husbandry, and rural affairs.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Agricultural Society of Kings County records, 1977.396, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One multipage document containing the Agricultural Society of Kings County's constitution, bylaws, list of officers, goals, dues list, and meeting minutes, dated March 1807.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
